page.title: 05AMERSHAM'S HISTORY
page.content: Amersham appears in the 1086 Domesday book as Agmondesham. Prehistoric in- habitants were nomadic and no remains of hut circles have been found here as in other Chiltern districts, though a looped Bronze age spearhead was found in the river Misbourne in 1956. A prehistoric trade route passed over Gore Hill and is marked by pudding stones. Gore Hill is reputedly the site of a bloody battle between Danes and Saxons.A Roman farming settlement was demolished when the Aylesbury Road was excavated between Coldmoreham farm and Shardeloes. During the Civil War many Royalist and Puritan troops marched through the town and Cromwell dined at the Griffin Hotel in the High Street.. Amersham was a staging-post for coaches, and you can still see many of the arches for the coaches.
